user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Initialize:
```c
void OS_BSP_Initialize(void)
{
    FILE *              fp;
    char                buffer[32];
    pthread_mutexattr_t mutex_attr;
    int                 status;

    /*
     * If not running as root, check /proc/sys/fs/mqueue/msg_max
     *
     * This special file represents the max depth of a POSIX message queue for an unprivileged user.
     *
     * In order to facilitate running in simulation mode without any need for root access --
     * this will allow the OSAL to successfully create message queues by truncating anything larger than this size.
     *
     * No need to check _LINUX_OS_ here; if the file fails to open, i.e. if not on Linux and the file does not exist,
     * then leave well enough alone and don't do anything.
     */
    if (geteuid() != 0)
    {
        fp = fopen("/proc/sys/fs/mqueue/msg_max", "r");
        if (fp)
        {
            if (fgets(buffer, sizeof(buffer), fp) != NULL)
            {
                OS_BSP_Global.MaxQueueDepth = OSAL_BLOCKCOUNT_C(strtoul(buffer, NULL, 10));
                BSP_DEBUG("Maximum user msg queue depth = %u\n", (unsigned int)OS_BSP_Global.MaxQueueDepth);
            }
            fclose(fp);
        }
    }

    /* Initialize the low level access mutex (w/priority inheritance) */
    status = pthread_mutexattr_init(&mutex_attr);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutexattr_init: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    status = pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol(&mutex_attr, PTHREAD_PRIO_INHERIT);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    status = pthread_mutex_init(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex, &mutex_attr);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_init: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BSP_Initialize:
#define OSAL_BLOCKCOUNT_C(X) ((osal_blockcount_t)(X))
...
#define BSP_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No for statements are present in the provided function or in the provided macro definitions. Rule 14.2 concerns the structure of for loops (their three clauses and loop-counter usage). Since there are no for loops in OS_BSP_Initialize, there are no fragments in this code that could violate Rule 14.2 and thus nothing to investigate for that rule. The two provided macros (OSAL_BLOCKCOUNT_C and BSP_DEBUG) expand to a simple cast and an empty expansion respectively and do not introduce any for loops. The calls to library/system functions (fopen, fgets, strtoul, pthread_mutexattr_init, pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol, pthread_mutex_init, fclose, etc.) are function calls only; any loops within those functions (not shown here) are not part of this translation unit fragment and cannot cause a violation of Rule 14.2 in this code fragment itself. Therefore no code fragments in the submitted code need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2.
